title: How X-rays see through your skin - Ge Wang

title: How to make a mummy - Len Bloch

title: Andy Warhol, Campbell's Soup Cans: Why is this Art?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it creates a beautiful representation of everyday life.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it criticizes the advertising industry.

options.label: D
options.text: That Warhol's artwork is only great because of its technical skill.

title: Can you solve the famously difficult green-eyed logic puzzle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition for a prisoner to be released from the island?

options.label: D
options.text: If they are over 30 years old.

multiple-choice.question: Why are the prisoners unable to learn their own eye color?

options.label: B
options.text: Because there are no reflective surfaces on the island.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the dictator has ensured they cannot learn their own eye color.

options.label: B
options.text: "At least one of you has green eyes."

options.text: By seeing each other still on the island the next morning.

options.text: By realizing the statement could only refer to themselves.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The prisoners would have stayed on the island forever.

options.text: Because the dictator is forced to by human rights groups.

options.label: D

title: Football physics: The "impossible" free kick - Erez Garty

multiple-choice.question: What is the Magnus effect in physics?

options.label: A
options.text: The phenomenon where an object moves in a straight line despite external forces.

options.label: B
options.text: The phenomenon where an object curves due to the difference in air pressure caused by its spin.

options.label: C
options.text: The phenomenon where an object accelerates due to the force applied to it.

options.label: D
options.text: The phenomenon where an object decelerates due to air resistance.

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with documenting the Magnus effect for the first time?

options.label: B
options.text: A kick with a lot of force but no direction

options.label: C
options.text: A kick that uses the Magnus effect to curve the ball

options.label: D
options.text: A kick that uses the wind to curve the ball

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The air pressure increases on one side and decreases on the other side of the ball

options.label: D

options.text: Because the ball's trajectory is affected by many factors, such as speed, spin, and direction

options.label: D
options.text: Because the ball always hits the ground before curving

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: At least 20 times faster than Roberto Carlos's kick

title: How to make an attractive city

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to chaos and mess.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of having visible life in a city, according to the manifesto?

options.label: C
options.text: It makes cities feel more alive and attractive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the third principle of making attractive cities, according to the manifesto?
Why is compactness important in a city, according to the manifesto?

options.label: A
options.text: It promotes the use of cars and lorries.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the energy consumption of a city.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes cities feel more alive and attractive.

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the environmental impact of a city.

options.label: A
options.text: To promote the use of cars and lorries.

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the energy consumption of a city.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide both the pleasures of mystery and the pleasures of orientation.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the environmental impact of a city.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with modern cities, according to the manifesto?

options.label: C
options.text: They prioritize commercial interests over human needs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main obstacle to building beautiful cities, according to the manifesto?

options.label: B

title: What’s the big deal with gluten? - William D. Chey

multiple-choice.question: What is gluten?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of protein found in certain grains, particularly wheat, rye, and barley.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of fiber found in fruits and vegetables.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of fat found in meats and dairy products.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of gluten in foods?

options.label: A
options.text: To add flavor and texture to foods.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide nutritional value to foods.

options.label: C
options.text: To give foods an elastic consistency and chewiness.

options.label: D
options.text: To preserve foods and extend their shelf life.

multiple-choice.question: What is celiac disease?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of wheat allergy that causes mild problems.

options.label: B
options.text: An inherited disease that causes inflammation and damage to the lining of the small intestine.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of gluten sensitivity that causes painful gut symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of food intolerance that causes digestive problems.

multiple-choice.question: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Medication to reduce inflammation and damage to the small intestine.

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery to repair the lining of the small intestine.

multiple-choice.question: What is non-celiac gluten sensitivity?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of wheat allergy that causes mild problems.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of gluten intolerance that causes painful gut symptoms.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition in which people experience symptoms when they eat foods with gluten, but do not have celiac disease or a wheat allergy.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of food intolerance that causes digestive problems.

multiple-choice.question: How is non-celiac gluten sensitivity diagnosed?

options.label: A
options.text: Through a blood test or tissue biopsy.

options.label: B
options.text: Through the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement on a gluten-free diet.

options.label: C
options.text: Through a physical examination and medical history.

multiple-choice.question: What is the nocebo effect?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon in which a person believes something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does.

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon in which a person believes something will have a positive effect, and because of that belief, it does.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of food intolerance that causes digestive problems.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of wheat allergy that causes mild problems.

multiple-choice.question: What is fructan?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of protein found in wheat and other grains.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of fiber found in fruits and vegetables.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of fat found in meats and dairy products.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to fructans in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: They are broken down and absorbed by the small intestine.

options.label: B
options.text: They are fermented by bacteria in the large intestine, producing short-chain fatty acids and gases.

options.label: C
options.text: They are excreted in the urine.

title: Sunlight is way older than you think - Sten Odenwald

multiple-choice.question: How long does it take for light to travel from the surface of the Sun to the Earth?

options.label: B
options.text: They interact with matter and lose energy, becoming longer wavelength forms of light.

options.label: C
options.text: They remain unchanged in terms of energy and wavelength.

options.label: D
options.text: They are absorbed by the Sun's core.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speed of a photon?

options.label: A
options.text: The question of how far a photon gets from the center of the Sun after each collision.

options.label: B
options.text: The question of how long it takes for a photon to travel from the Sun's core to its surface.

options.label: C
options.text: The question of how much energy a photon loses as it interacts with matter.

options.label: D
options.text: The question of how many protons a photon collides with.

multiple-choice.question: What is the formula for calculating the distance traveled by a photon in a random walk?

options.label: A
options.text: Distance = step size x number of steps

options.label: B
options.text: Distance = step size x square root of number of steps

options.label: C
options.text: Distance = step size / number of steps

options.label: D
options.text: Distance = step size / square root of number of steps

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated time it takes for a photon to travel from the Sun's core to its surface?

options.label: A
options.text: The Sun is not actually of uniform density.

options.label: B
options.text: Photons will miss quite a few protons between every collision.

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B are correct.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B is correct.

multiple-choice.question: What determines how likely a photon is to interact with a proton?

options.label: C
options.text: The density of the Sun's core

options.label: D
options.text: The temperature of the Sun's surface

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between a photon's energy and its likelihood of interacting with a proton?

options.label: A
options.text: High-energy photons are more likely to interact with protons.

options.label: B
options.text: Low-energy photons are more likely to interact with protons.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no relationship between a photon's energy and its likelihood of interacting with a proton.

options.label: D
options.text: The relationship is random and unpredictable.

multiple-choice.question: When did the photons that are hitting the Earth today begin their journey from the Sun's core?
